items.title: What if all patterns were proven?
items.content:
You'd have: A static playbook, no experimentation needed.
Why this fails: Claude Code evolves weekly. New capabilities emerge. Communities discover combinations.
Hidden constraint: Frontier exists BECAUSE the tool improves faster than documentation can validate.

items.title: Who should explore frontier?
items.content:
Beginner: Not yet - master basics first
Intermediate: Read for inspiration, don't implement
Advanced: Prototype one innovation at a time
Staff: Design your own frontier combinations
Expert: Contribute back to community

items.title: Proven vs. Frontier
items.content:
Proven patterns: Reliable, documented, community-tested
Frontier patterns: Higher ceiling, higher risk, less support

Rule: Use proven for production, frontier for R&D.

items.title: Top 3 Unexplored Combinations
items.content:
1. Ralph Colonies: CC Mirror swarm where each agent runs Ralph internally
2. Self-Scaling Ralph: Ralph loop that spawns/terminates colonies based on load
3. Skeptical Panopticon: Domain agents that challenge each other's claims

items.title: Frontier = Feature Flags
items.content:
Feature flags let you test new behavior safely.
Frontier patterns = feature flags for your workflow.

You don't deploy untested features to production. Don't deploy untested patterns either.

items.title: Why "Innovation Combinations"?
items.content:
ROOT: Individual patterns are documented
→ But combinations are not
→ Combinations create emergent properties
→ Emergent properties can't be predicted from parts
→ Therefore: combinations must be explored, not derived

items.title: The Paradigm Shift
items.content:
2020: "Development requires a laptop and focus time"
2024: "Development can happen from your phone"
2025: "Your phone is a command center for AI agents"
Future: "Agents work while you live your life"

items.title: @dabit3's Vision
items.content:
"Instead of long periods of intense focus, software development can now just fit into the gaps of your day."

Start agents in the morning. Review on the train. Approve from lunch. Ship before dinner.

items.title: Mobile Development MVP
items.content:
Phone -> SSH -> tmux -> Claude Code

That's it. Everything else is optimization.

items.title: Claude Code 2.1+
items.content:
Before 2.1: English-only interface, workarounds needed
After 2.1: Native multilingual response configuration

The inflection: International developers went from "it works but awkward" to "it works natively."

items.title: Code Stays English
items.content:
Regardless of response language, code remains English:
- Variable names
- Function signatures
- File paths

Why: Git, npm, most tooling assumes ASCII. This is a global invariant.

items.title: Language Tier Guide
items.content:
Tier 1 (Native): EN, JA, ES, FR, DE, PT, ZH
Tier 2 (Strong): KO, IT, NL, RU, AR
Tier 3 (Good): HI, TR, PL, VI, TH

Match your language to expected fluency.

items.title: If you skip the prerequisites...
items.content:
IF: Jump to Ralph Colonies without mastering Ralph
THEN: Can't debug colony failures (is it Ralph or coordination?)
THEN: Blame the pattern instead of your understanding
FINALLY: Abandon promising innovation due to false negative

items.title: Best First Experiment
items.content:
Ralph + Memory Compaction
You already use progress.txt. Add automatic compaction after 20KB.

Why: Smallest delta from current practice, immediate measurable benefit.
